fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of a woman, formerly said to be Anne Scott, Duchess of Monmouth and Buccleuch, watercolour on vellum, English School, ca.1670.
fields.physical_description:
Portrait of a woman, head and shoulders and facing to front.  Features in large soft strokes of brown and sanguine, with bright blue and blue-green stippled shading and broad coarse sanguine hatches crossing the features and neck diagonally, on a very pale carnation ground; hair in pale brown wash, hatched and lined in darker colour with the lights 
in pale gouache with some blue touches; chemise in white wash modelled in grey; the costume freely washed with ultramarine and lake, with the lights in white; background in ochre gouache over blue (originally intended to be a sky?) with some opaque blue stipple superimposed; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. 

<u>Frame:</u> Twentieth-century oval frame of turned ebonised fruitwood; the sides rounded, rising through a complex series of mouldings before descending sharply to a narrow black fillet above an inner ring of gilded wood forming the upper surface of the rebate, which holds the shallowly convex glass; the hanger a simple brass ring held by a small staple driven into the frame.
fields.title: A Woman, formerly said to be Anne Scott, Duchess of Monmouth and Buccleuch
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum  put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.198, pp. 327-328. Full citation: "A Woman, formerly said to be Anne Scott, Duchess of Monmouth and Buccleuch (b. 1651 d.1732) c. 1670 Evans 50 Oval 83 x 68 mm Features in large soft strokes of brown and sanguine, with bright blue and blue-green stippled shading and broad coarse sanguine hatches crossing the features and neck diagonally, on a very pale carnation ground; hair in pale brown wash, hatched and lined in darker colour with the lights in pale gouache with some blue touches; chemise in white wash modelled in grey; the costume freely washed with ultramarine and lake, with the lights in white; background in ochre gouache over blue (originally intended to be a sky?) with some opaque blue stipple superimposed; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Possibly much restored and repainted, though only minor damages and retouches are certainly visible. Signed: Not signed. Frame: Twentieth-century oval frame of turned ebonised fruitwood; the sides rounded, rising through a complex series of mouldings before descending sharply to a narrow black fillet above an inner ring of gilded wood forming the upper surface of the rebate, which holds the shallowly convex glass; the hanger a simple brass ring held by a small staple driven into the frame. Provenance: Acquired by the Hon. F H A Wallop from an unrecorded source and placed on loan at the V&A 1929-49; the ownership transferred to Alan Evans, 1933, and by him bequeathed to the National Gallery, 1974; placed on indeterminate loan at the V&A. (See Appendix 3.) Literature: Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 78 (as Duchess of Buccleuch, probably early eighteenth century). Various attributions have been advanced: by Wallop, with Long's tacit acquiescence, to Nicholas Dixon or 'Lawrence Crosse'; (1) by the valuer for Christie's 1969 valuation to Charles Beale. None of these is right, and the miniature seems more likely, given its polychrome stipple and its striation, to be a copy after Peter Cross or perhaps Richard Gibson. The style of Gibson's children (with the exception of 'S P Rosse) is completely unknown, however, and one or other might have painted in this way, synthesising their father's dense painterly manner with the lighter and more fashionable stipple of Cross. The work, as far as can be seen through what seems to be restoration, is competent, and technically in fair accord with professional London practice in the later seventeenth century. Wallop's identification of the sitter as Anne Scott seems to have no firm basis. Comparison of the likeness with the accepted images of her in the various Buccleuch houses is not encouraging. The main types are by Lely c. 1670, of which there is a copy by Mary Beale; (2) by Wissing, c.1680 onwards; and a very similar Kneller of about the same date-span. The Lely provides the best comparison as to date, but little resemblance in feature. The portraiture of an eminent lady such as Anne Scott, suo jure Countess of Buccleuch and widow of the Duke of Monmouth, would have been subject to proliferation and variation by painters in all media, so this could be an unrecorded image of her. But there is no evidence that it is, and she is very much the sort of person whose name is optimistically attached to anonymous portraits of about the right date. 1 Wallop Loan Book, p. 160. 2 Formerly Leggatt Bros, photo NPG."
fields.credit: Alan Evans Bequest, given by the National Gallery
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Acquired by the Hon. F H A Wallop from an unrecorded source and placed on loan at the V&A 1929-49; the ownership transferred to Alan Evans, 1933, and by him bequeathed to the National Gallery, 1974; placed on indeterminate loan at the V&A.
